description:
Botrytis cinerea B05.10 is a filamentous fungal species that belongs to the Ascomycota phylum. It is a necrotrophic plant pathogen, known for causing gray mold disease in a wide range of economically important crops, including fruits, vegetables, and ornamental plants.

The B05.10 strain is a well-studied model organism within the Botrytis cinerea species, as it has been extensively used in genetic and molecular research. This strain exhibits significant genetic and phenotypic variations compared to other Botrytis cinerea isolates, making it a valuable tool for understanding the underlying mechanisms of pathogenicity, host-pathogen interactions, and fungal biology.

Botrytis cinerea B05.10 produces gray, fluffy mycelia and develops conidiophores that bear gray, branched conidia, which are the primary means of asexual reproduction and dispersal. The fungus can also produce sclerotia, which are compact structures that allow the pathogen to survive adverse environmental conditions.

Understanding the biology and genomics of Botrytis cinerea B05.10 has important implications for the development of effective disease management strategies, as well as for advancing our knowledge of fungal pathogenesis and the fundamental processes governing plant-microbe interactions.
